conclusion: The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A→B is isothermal expansion, B→C is isochoric cooling, C→D is isothermal compression, D→A is isochoric heating.
The transition from state B to state C is an isochoric process where volume remains constant and pressure decreases.
Thermal motion of gas molecules is related to temperature; higher temperature means more intense thermal motion.
For an ideal gas, temperature is proportional to the product of pressure and volume (PV = nRT).
Since volume is constant during B→C, temperature is directly proportional to pressure.
In the P-V diagram, during B→C, volume remains constant (vertical line) and pressure decreases.
During B→C, temperature decreases as pressure decreases.
As temperature decreases, thermal motion becomes less intense.
Lower temperature means average kinetic energy of gas molecules decreases, reducing thermal motion.
No, thermal motion does not become more intense when transitioning from B to C; it becomes less intense.
